description: Psycholinguistic Architecture specification for FrameLord business frame analysis

axes.name: Locus of Control
axes.description: Degree to which user attributes outcomes to their own actions (internal) vs. external forces (external)

axes.name: Motivation Direction
axes.description: Balance between moving towards goals vs. away from problems

axes.name: Process Clarity
axes.description: Degree of structured methodology vs. chaotic improvisation

axes.name: Linguistic Authority
axes.description: Use of command language vs. powerless language markers
axes.lowMeaning: Hedges, minimizers, tag questions, seeking permission

axes.name: Pricing Confidence
axes.description: Comfort level with money and value conversations

axes.name: Status Frame
axes.description: Power dynamics in interactions (Supplicant < Analyst < Power)

axes.name: Boundary Control
axes.description: Ability to enforce limits and handle conflict
axes.lowMeaning: Conflict avoidance, passive aggression, boundary leaks
axes.highMeaning: Direct, firm boundaries, comfortable with tension

axes.name: Operational Congruence
axes.description: Alignment between stated goals and actual behaviors (say-do gap)
axes.lowMeaning: Say-do gap, temporal gaps, avoidance behaviors

axes.name: Frame Strength
axes.description: Overall dominance of Power vs. Analyst vs. Supplicant patterns

flags.description: High passive voice density, external attribution dominance - user believes they have no control over outcomes
User attributes outcomes to luck/others, feels pressured by obligation rather than internal choice
User operates from low status, seeking permission/validation through hedges and tag questions
User has internalized negative money scripts, shows discomfort with value through apologetic/euphemistic language
User resents wealth, uses negative adjectives for high-price providers, likely sabotages own pricing
User lacks confidence in value, immediately explains features after stating price
User doesn't internalize success, attributes to luck/timing, fears being 'found out'
User operates from low power, gives away frame control through permission-seeking and acquiescence
Conflict avoidance, fear of client loss, acquiescence to unreasonable demands
Say-do gap between stated goals and actual behaviors, temporal gaps indicating avoidance
Fear of rejection, social anxiety around outreach, 'bothering people' language
User avoids necessary confrontations through passive aggressive or indirect communication
User expresses frustration indirectly through low status communication patterns
User has limiting beliefs creating distorted reality through universal quantifiers
Possible deception, distancing, or lack of conviction through pronoun divergence
User views problems as static states rather than processes they can change
User lacks true commitment, uses future tense without dates, wishful thinking

detectors.name: Passive Voice Detector
detectors.description: Identifies passive voice constructions that obscure agency
patternHints: be verb + past participle without agent

detectors.name: Pronoun Density Analysis
detectors.description: Calculates first-person pronoun usage relative to total words

detectors.name: Pronoun Divergence Detector
detectors.description: Identifies shifts from first-person to third-person pronouns at critical moments

detectors.name: Hedge Density Calculator
detectors.description: Counts hedges and minimizers indicating low confidence

detectors.name: Temporal Gap Detector
detectors.description: Identifies time bridges that hide unproductive periods

detectors.name: Text Bridge Analyzer
detectors.description: Similar to temporal gaps, identifies narrative bridges that skip details

detectors.name: Universal Quantifier Detector
detectors.description: Identifies overgeneralizations that indicate limiting beliefs

detectors.name: Modal Necessity Detector
detectors.description: Identifies modal operators of necessity indicating external pressure

detectors.name: Modal Possibility Detector
detectors.description: Identifies modal operators of possibility indicating choice

detectors.name: Nominalization Detector
detectors.description: Identifies verbs turned into nouns, removing action from language

detectors.name: Tag Question Detector
detectors.description: Identifies tag questions that seek validation

detectors.name: Towards Language Detector
detectors.description: Identifies motivation language focused on goals and accumulation

detectors.name: Away Language Detector
detectors.description: Identifies motivation language focused on avoidance and problems

detectors.name: External Attribution Detector
detectors.description: Identifies attribution of outcomes to external factors

detectors.name: Internal Attribution Detector
detectors.description: Identifies attribution of outcomes to own actions

detectors.name: Supplicant Language Detector
detectors.description: Identifies low-status, permission-seeking language patterns

detectors.name: Power Language Detector
detectors.description: Identifies high-status, commanding language patterns

detectors.name: Minimizer Detector
detectors.description: Identifies language that minimizes value or apologizes for asking

detectors.name: Money Apology Detector
detectors.description: Identifies apologetic language around pricing

detectors.name: Price Euphemism Detector
detectors.description: Identifies euphemistic language that avoids direct pricing terms

detectors.name: Price Justification Detector
detectors.description: Identifies immediate feature explanation after price statement

detectors.name: Wealth Adjective Test Analyzer
detectors.description: Analyzes adjectives used to describe high-price providers

detectors.name: Success Attribution Analyzer
detectors.description: Analyzes whether user attributes success to self or external factors

detectors.name: Boundary Acquiescence Detector
detectors.description: Identifies acquiescence to unreasonable demands

detectors.name: Boundary Enforcement Detector
detectors.description: Identifies firm boundary statements

detectors.name: Passive Aggressive Pattern Detector
detectors.description: Identifies indirect expression of frustration

detectors.name: Conflict Avoidance Pattern Detector
detectors.description: Identifies patterns indicating fear of confrontation
patternHints: I don't want to be pushy

detectors.name: Avoidance Language Detector
detectors.description: Identifies language indicating call reluctance or prospecting avoidance

detectors.name: Vague Future Tense Detector
detectors.description: Identifies future commitments without specific dates

detectors.name: Sequential Marker Detector
detectors.description: Identifies clear sequential process language

detectors.name: Conditional Language Detector
detectors.description: Identifies conditional/tentative language indicating lack of process

questions.prompt: In one or two sentences, tell me who you are and what you do for a living.
What kind of work or projects occupy most of your time right now?
If FrameLord works perfectly for you, what does your life or business look like six months from now?
questions.hint: Paint a vivid picture of your ideal outcome.

questions.prompt: List three specific things you want to achieve, change, or stop doing.
questions.hint: Be specific—numbers, names, dates if you have them.

questions.prompt: Describe the last significant deal or project that didn't go your way. What was the primary factor that caused the outcome?
questions.hint: Walk through what happened step by step.

questions.prompt: What is the single most important change you want to see in your business over the next 90 days?
questions.hint: Focus on one priority, not a list.

questions.prompt: Walk me through your typical sales or influence process from first contact to commitment.
questions.hint: Describe the steps you usually follow.

questions.prompt: What is the one habit, pattern, or constraint that you suspect is holding you back the most?
questions.hint: Be honest—this stays between you and the system.

questions.prompt: Is there anything else you think the system should know about you before we begin?
questions.hint: Skip if nothing comes to mind.

questions.prompt: Without being modest, how strong is your current frame in real life?
questions.hint: 1 = fragile, 10 = Apex. Be honest with yourself.

questions.prompt: Imagine you must double your price tomorrow. Write the email you would send to your best client explaining this change.
What is your earliest memory of your family discussing money? How does that memory surface physically when you send an invoice today?
If a client says 'That's too expensive,' what is the literal first thought that flashes in your mind?
Complete this sentence: 'People who charge high prices are _______.'
When you state your price, do you pause and wait, or do you immediately explain the features?
Describe a recent success you achieved. How much of that result was due to your specific skill, and how much was due to luck or timing?
When you enter a meeting with a high-net-worth prospect, who is the 'Prize' in the room? Why?
A client demands you jump on a call immediately, disrupting your schedule. You have no urgent meetings, but you intended to do deep work. What do you say?
Why did you win your biggest deal?
Walk me through yesterday, step-by-step, from the moment you started work to the moment you finished. Be specific.
You mentioned you want to reach [Goal X]. What is the one thing you know you should be doing to get there, but haven't done in the last week?
A client is late on an invoice. Draft the reminder text.
